If you require further assistance, you can consult the Cloudflare Community where thousands of users, experts, and staff providing technical advice and support. Most users get a reply within 24 hours on the Cloudflare Community.

Search the community to find answers for issues just like yours
If you still need help, post a topic in the community
support.alt.step_select_zone.technical.d: Select a **Domain** and describe your issue in the **Summary** box to get self-service content suggestions and run our automated diagnostics. For technical issues, users on our Free plan have access to our self-service support content as well as our Community. If you wish to submit a case for 1:1 support from Cloudflare, you must upgrade your plan type.

support.alt.step_related_content.account:
Most of our customers are able to resolve their issues utilizing our self-service content.

Adding a new domain or site to your account?
Read this short guide or watch the video on adding a site to Cloudflare.

Do you want to grant another person access to manage your account?
Our guide Managing members shows you how to add or revoke access for other users to manage your account.

Do you want to change your Cloudflare plan?
You can do this in the dashboard today by following change plan type.

Want to delete your account?
You can do this instantly today by following delete your Cloudflare account.
support.alt.step_related_content.billing:
Most of our customers are able to resolve their issues utilizing our self-service content.

Solve your failed payment issue right now.
Follow our guide to the most Common Reasons for Failed Payment.

Cancelling your paid subscription?
It just takes 2 easy steps to cancel your subscription.

Questions about your invoice?
We recommend reading Understanding Cloudflare invoices.

Changing your Billing address or adding VAT/GST information?
You can do this immediately via our dashboard by following Updating Billing Information.
support.alt.step_related_content.footer: Still need help? Click Next to provide more details about your issue.
support.alt.step_related_content.registr:
Most of our customers are able to resolve their issues utilizing our self-service content.

Transferring a domain to Cloudflare Registrar?
Make sure your domain is in our list of Supported TLDs and if it is, follow our step by step guide to Domain Transfers.

Are you attempting to transfer out of Cloudflare Registrar?
Follow the Transfer out from Cloudflare guide.

Renewing a domain?
Follow our renewing domains guide here. Always make sure your chosen payment method has not rejected any charges from us and then you can retry a manual renewal.

support.error_analytics.title: Error Analytics
support.error_analytics.help:
The **Errors Over Time** graph and the **Top Requests** details are based on a 1% traffic sample.

The **Requests** column shows the number of HTTP Status Codes served. **Error Rate** column shows the percentage of all requests. For example, for 50 requests returning HTTP Error 502 out of 10,000 requests in 24-hours, the Error Rate for HTTP 502 errors is 0.5%.

Find help to diagnose and resolve 5XX errors for Cloudflare proxied sites at [Troubleshooting Cloudflare 5XX errors](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.desc: To help you identify common issues
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.clie: The origin web server for %{zoneName} is returning a HTTP [4xx client error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003014512). Cloudflare does not generate these error messages. Contact your hosting provider for help.

The origin web server for %{zoneName} is returning a high percentage of HTTP [4xx client errors](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003014512). Cloudflare does not generate these error messages. Contact your hosting provider for help.
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.cnam: Since you have a CNAME set-up, you need to add a verification TXT record to your authoritative DNS before Cloudflare can activate your domain. We couldn't find a valid verification DNS record for %{zoneName}. Review [Configuring a CNAME setup](https://developers.cloudflare.com/dns/zone-setups/partial-setup).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.dns_: You are missing DNS records for your domain root (%{zoneName}) or the www subdomain (www.%{zoneName}). You'll see [err_name_not_resolved errors](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/217912538) when accessing a (sub)domain with missing DNS records. Review [Managing DNS records in Cloudflare](https://developers.cloudflare.com/dns/manage-dns-records/how-to/create-dns-records).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.mixe: %{zoneName} has mixed content errors. Mixed content disrupts content delivery over HTTPS because some of the resources requested are served over HTTP. If this error occurs, a green lock does not appear when serving HTTPS traffic. Review [How do I fix the SSL Mixed Content Error Message?](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200170476).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.name: The authoritative nameservers for %{zoneName} are set incorrectly. For Cloudflare to activate, your domain registrar must point to the two nameservers provided by Cloudflare as the authoritative servers. Set your authoritative nameservers in your registrar's admin panel (contact your registrar for support). Review [changing your nameservers](https://developers.cloudflare.com/dns/zone-setups/full-setup).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.redi: %{zoneName} has a redirect loop error. This error often leads to website downtime and has two common causes: an incorrect SSL setting or forced HTTPS redirects., review our guide on [troubleshooting redirect loops](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115000219871).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.serv: %{zoneName} is returning a HTTP 5xx server error. Review [5xx Server Error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).
%{zoneName} is returning a high percentage of HTTP 5xx server errors Review [5xx Server Error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.slow: The origin web server for %{zoneName} is responding slowly to initial requests for uncached HTML content. To remove this performance bottleneck, look at your server's ability to return HTML faster and/or implement HTML caching in Cloudflare. You may benefit from [caching static HTML and anonymous page views](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cache/best-practices/customize-cache). Learn how to do this in: [WordPress](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236166048), [Drupal](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115002911927) and [Magento](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236168808).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.ssl_: %{zoneName} does not have a valid SSL certificate. It may take up to 24 hours to issue a new SSL certificate. Make sure that the domain is correctly set up in Cloudflare. Review [Why isn't SSL working for my site?](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200170566).
support.error_analytics.diagnostics.stat: %{zoneName} is returning a significant percentage of HTTP 5xx server errors. Check Server Error Report here and review [5xx Server Error](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115003011431).

support.phone_support.description:
In the event of a critical issue, Enterprise customers may contact our 24x7 emergency hotline. Regional numbers for the emergency hotline can be found on the [Enterprise Portal](https://cloudflare.com/ecp/support).

To help us verify your identity, click a button to generate:
* a single-use token per call, or
* an authenticator app token on your mobile device. You can use a two-factor app like Google Authenticator.

support.forgot_email.description: This tool helps determine the email address associated to your Cloudflare account. Provide your active Cloudflare domain in the form below to email the address on file. Enterprise customers cannot utilize this tool and must contact their Account Manager.

support.forgot_email.registered:
Thank you for providing those details. If that domain is active on Cloudflare, we have notified the email address on file. If you haven't received an email after 20 minutes, check your spam folder. The message will be sent from 'no-reply@cloudflare.com' or 'noreply@notify.cloudflare.com'. If you can't find the email, you can start the recovery process again or enter a different domain in your account.

If you have lost access to the original email address used to sign up for your Cloudflare account, review the following article: u201C[I lost the email address associated with my Cloudflare account, what do I do?](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/203471284#12345681)u201D

support.step_diagnostics.backlog_message:
Dear valued customer,

Due to the current global pandemic crisis, Cloudflare has seen a large increase in Internet traffic through our network, and is experiencing a large increase in customer case volume. This has resulted in longer than normal delays in inquiry response. We apologize for this delay and inconvenience. If your question is not urgent or high priority, in lieu of submitting a case, please consult our extensive [knowledge base](https://support.cloudflare.com/), [developer docs](https://developers.cloudflare.com/), and [community](https://community.cloudflare.com/) to find the answer to your question. This is the fastest way for quick assistance with general questions.  However, if your request is urgent or high priority, please submit a case for support.

Thanks for your understanding and help.

Cloudflare Customer Support Team
support.step_diagnostics.texas_backlog_m:
Dear valued customer,

Due to the current emergency weather situation in Texas, we are seeing delays in average response times for non-Enterprise customers. We apologize for this inconvenience.

If your question is not urgent or high priority, in lieu of submitting a case, please consult our extensive [knowledge base](https://support.cloudflare.com/), [developer docs](https://developers.cloudflare.com/), and [community](https://community.cloudflare.com/) to find the answer to your question. This is the fastest way for quick assistance with general questions.  However, if your request is urgent or high priority, please submit a case for support.

Thanks for your understanding and help.

Cloudflare Customer Support Team

support.portal.self-help-wizard.400.four: Are you getting this error when using the Cloudflare API? (for the hostname `api.cloudflare.com`)
Do you see the `server: cloudflare` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.
Have you confirmed that all the special characters in the the request are percent-encoded?
For example make sure that `%test` is encoded as `%25test`
Do you see both `Transfer-Encoding` and `Content-Length` headers present in the request?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.
Do you get a blank error page with the message `The plain HTTP request was sent to HTTPS port - cloudflare`?

The full HTML code of the page is: `` `400 The plain HTTP request was sent to HTTPS port` `` `

400 Bad Request

` `
The plain HTTP request was sent to HTTPS port
` `
cloudflare
` `` ``
Do you get a blank white error page `400 Bad Request - cloudflare`?

400 Bad Request clouflare

The full HTML code of the page is: `` `400 Bad Request` `` `

400 Bad Request

` `
cloudflare
` `` ``

This indicates that Cloudflare does not understand the request. Please make sure that the request is properly formatted and complies with RFC standards. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details. If you need to submit a case, please provide a HAR file.

You should be able to find these 400 errors in the access logs of your origin web server in order to investigate further. The following resources might help: - NGINX Logs - Apache Logs You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. If an unexpected origin web server was reached, it might not understand the request and return the 400 response code. Please make sure that the DNS record configured under DNS -> Records on the Cloudflare Dashboard for the requested hostname has the expected value. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

You are getting this error because you are trying to send non-secure HTTP traffic to a secure HTTPS port (443, 2053, 2083, 2087, 2096, 8443). You'll need to either change the scheme to `HTTPS://` instead of `HTTP://`, or make sure the `HTTP://` request is directed to a non-secure HTTP port. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

Previously, RFC 2616 allowed the use of `Transfer-Encoding` and `Content-Length` HTTP headers in the same request. RFC 7230 supersedes RFC 2616 and prohibits the use of `Transfer-Encoding` and `Content-Length` headers in the same request because they can cause HTTP request smuggling vulnerabilities. Read our deprecation notice for more details, and you can also read our 4xx Client Error article.

Please make sure all the characters in the URL of the request are percent-encoded. If a special character (like `%`) is not encoded then an HTTP Error 400 is returned. For example `example.com/%test/` would return an HTTP Error 400. The correct syntax is `example.com/%25test/`. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

This means that the request is not proxied by Cloudflare. The 400 error is served by your origin web server. You need to check the access log on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Logs - Apache Logs You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

The Error 400 Bad Request is thrown when the client did not send a correct request to the server. Please review the Cloudflare API documentation and make sure youu2019re using the correct formatting and syntax, and that all the mandatory parameters are present in your request (in the path, query string and body). Read our 4xx Client Error and Cloudflare Fundamental API articles for more details.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.403.four: I'm getting an HTTP Error 403
Is the domain on which youu2019re getting the error 403 part of your Cloudflare account?
You can find the list of zones that you manage in the home page of your Cloudflare Dashboard.
Is the 403 error page a Cloudflare branded error page or a Custom Error Page you have configured?
Custom Error Pages can be created at the zone or account level.
Is the error presented with a white page containing only `403 Forbidden - Cloudflare`?
Does the 403 error page mention `Cloudflare` at all?
Is the error reported by a bot, crawler or external service such as Google?
Error 403 may be reported in the Google Search Console, Bing Webmaster Tools or similar services.
Are you getting this 403 error in a browser?
Have you confirmed that you see the `server: cloudflare` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.

This means that the request was not proxied by Cloudflare, and that the 403 error is served by your origin web server. Youu2019ll need to check the access log and security features on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Security Controls - Apache Security Tips You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

Since the error is not Cloudflare branded but is being returned via Cloudflare, this means that the HTTP 403 response was returned by your origin server and proxied through Cloudflare. Youu2019ll need to check the access log and security features on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Security Controls - Apache Security Tips You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. If the Cloudflare zone is on the Enterprise plan, you can use the Cloudlfare Logs to get more details about the request. You can confirm using the field `OriginResponseStatus` if the 403 response code is returned by your origin. You can check the Security Events on your Cloudflare Dashboard to check for request blocked or challenged by Cloudflare Security features. If necessary, use the Skip action to exclude specific URLs from rule application.

Please review the headers and the content of the error page, and check again whether this is a Cloudflare branded error or not. You can use the Developer Tools in your browser to get more details about the request. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

Cloudflare by default allows verified bots. You can check your Security Events in your Cloudflare Dashboard under Security -> Events to make sure you are not blocking or challenging Google bots (or other relevant crawling bots). If necessary, use the Skip action to exclude specific URLs or specific bots from rule application. If the Cloudflare zone is on the Enterprise plan, you can use the Cloudflare Logs to get more details about the request. You can confirm using the field `OriginResponseStatus` if the 403 response code is returned by your origin.

In this case the error 403 is served by your origin web server. Youu2019ll need to check the access log and security features on your origin web server. The following resources might help: - NGINX Security Controls - Apache Security Tips You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

A blank page with `403 Forbidden - Cloudflare` in the body can be caused by a mismatch between the host header and requested host (URI). Please check that you are requesting the expected hostname, and that this hostname is configured on the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) of the certificate presented by Cloudflare. If you're using a proxy or load balancer in between the affected clients and Cloudflare, you might need to review the SNI configuration of these applications. Please also note that local endpoint security applications (like antivirus) might affect the connection from a client to Cloudflare as they might install a local root certificate to be able to decrypt and analyze traffic. Please also check that your browser is supported and that you're using a supported cipher suite. The openssl tool might be helpful to try to reproduce the issue and investigate further on your side: `openssl s_client -connect :443 -servername `

In this case a Cloudflare security feature has blocked or challenged the request. Youu2019ll need to check the Security Events in your Cloudflare Dashboard under Security -> Events. If necessary, use the Skip action to exclude specific URLs from rule application. If you need assistance configuring the WAF Managed Rules, please select the Technical - Website -> Security category to get further assistance in our Support Portal. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details.

If you are being blocked or challenged, please get in touch with the website owner to inquire for the specific reason. There are several common reasons a Cloudflare-protected website may block or challenge a site visitor: - The visitoru2019s IP address demonstrated previous suspicious activity online. Review your client IP address for malicious activity at Project Honeypot. - The website owner is using the Web Application Firewall (WAF) to block or challenge specific requests. - The visitoru2019s actions triggered a WAF Managed Rules enabled by the website owner.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.404.four: When you test on your origin web server directly, do you also get a 404?
If needed you can pause Cloudflare temporarily to check the response without the request getting proxied by Cloudflare.
Do you see the `server: cloudflare` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.
Have you confirmed that the 404 response is coming from the expected origin web server?

You can check the DNS configuration of your hostname in the Cloudflare Dashboard under DNS -> Records, and you might need to review your origin configuration (Load Balancers, proxies) and access logs.
Do you see the `CF-Cache-Status: HIT` header in the HTTP response youu2019re getting?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers, see our documentation here.

Cloudflare does not generate 404 errors, so this would indicate something is not configured correctly on your origin web server. It's possible that a document root with your origin is pointed to the wrong hostname or a different working directory. You should be able to find these 404 errors in the access logs of your origin web server. The HTTP status code 499 is an nginx specific response code to indicate when the connection has been closed by the client while the server is still processing its request, making the server unable to send a status code back. Since Cloudflare was built on nginx, we also have a 499 HTTP code in Cloudflare logs and analytics for connections which are terminated before we have finished processing the request. It is expected behavior to see these in your logs intermittently as clients close connections. Please note that Cloudflare has a 15 second timeout when connecting to the origin web server, and that the connection is attempted twice. So if the client has a shorter timeout than 30 seconds they will give up the connection even before Cloudflare receives a response from the origin, and thus Cloudflare logs the 499 status code. Read our 4xx Client Error article for more details. We also recommend you to confirm with your website visitors that they actually encountered faulty behavior at the time the HTTP status code 499 were logged: they might not have noticed any issue.

Please check and make sure HTTP/2 is correctly configured at the origin web server. Cloudflare connects to servers who announce support of HTTP/2 connections via ALPN. If the origin web server accepts the HTTP/2 connection but then doesn't respect or support the protocol, an HTTP Error 520 will be returned. You can try to disable the HTTP/2 to Origin setting on the Cloudflare Dashboard under Speed -> Optimization -> Protocol Optimization and check your origin web server configuration further. The most common cause of a HTTP 520 error is the origin server resetting the TCP connection during the response. Cloudflare cannot know why your origin server does this, only your origin server hosting provider or server administrator can inform you further.

We recommend that you contact them and carefully check the origin server health and error logs when this happens to understand why a TCP reset may be occurring.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.opt-: Having issues with Bot Management or Bot Fight Mode?
Answer some simple questions and receive an immediate solution. Note: If your site is under a DDoS attack, please choose our 'DDoS / Under Attack' category.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.enab: I am having trouble enabling Bot Fight Mode or Super Bot Fight Mode

**To check if your domain has Bot Fight Mode enabled:** - Go to **Security** > Bots - For Bot Fight Mode, select **On** **To check if your domain has Super Bot Fight Mode enabled:** * Go to **Security** > **Bots** > Configure Super Bot Fight Mode * Change the action for each rule as needed
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.anal: I am having trouble analyzing and finding bot related actions

**For Bot Fight Mode:** * Go to **Security** > Events * In the **Service** field, filter by **Bot Fight Mode** **For Super Bot Fight Mode:** * Go to **Security** > Events * In the **Service** field, filter by **Managed rules** **Note**: All requests blocked or challenged by bot can be seen. This allows to observe, analyze, and follow trends in your bot traffic over time.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.fp: Bot Fight Mode or Super Bot Fight Mode is causing problems with my application traffic (e.g. false positive)
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.fp.f: Due to the high security threshold, false positives do sometimes happen. If you turned on Bot Fight Mode or Super Bot Fight Mode during an attack, and the attack has subsided, we recommend either disabling the feature, use IP access rules to bypass Bot Fight Mode (BFM will be disabled if there are any IP access rules present), or upgrade to Bot Management for Enterprise. **How to disable BFM/SBFM feature?** * For Free plan, toggle the **Bot Fight Mode** option to **Off** under **Security** > Bots * For Pro, Business and Enterprise (no Bot Management add-on) plans: use the **Skip** action in Custom Rules to specify where Super Bot Fight Mode should not run. Skip rules are only available to customers who have migrated from Custom Rules to Firewall Rules.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.bfm.allo: I run a good bot and want for it to be added to the allowlist

Cloudflare maintains a sample list of verified bots in Cloudflare Radar. To get a good-bot verified and added to the allowed list, submit the Bot Verification Form. **Must read**: In order to be listed by Cloudflare as a Verified Bot, your bot must conform to the requirements in the Cloudflare Verified Bots Policy.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.shield.o: If you are having issues with scripts, alerts or CSP errors, click Start for an immediate solution.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.shield.n: Why can't I see scripts after enabling Page Shield?

Page Shield does not collect data on every single page view. Instead, it uses a sampling approach to gather information efficiently. This means that domains with lower traffic might take longer to generate initial reports, as these domains need more page views to accumulate enough samples. To speed up the reporting process, it is recommended that you actively generate traffic to your application after activating Page Shield. This will provide Page Shield with more data to work with, leading to faster report generation.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.shield.u: Why do I see scripts that I do not recognize?
Scripts often reference other scripts outside your application. But, if you see unexpected scripts on your Script Monitor dashboard, check them for signs of malicious activity.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.shield.w: Why do I see warnings in my browseru2019s developer tools related to Content Security Policy (CSP)?

Page Shield uses a Content Security Policy (CSP) report-only directive to gather a list of all scripts running on your application.
 
Some browsers display scripts being reported as warnings in the console pane of their developer tools. For example:
 
`[Report Only] Refused to execute inline script because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: **script-src 'none'**. Either the **'unsafe-inline'** keyword, a hash ('sha256-RFWPLDbv2BY+rCkDzsE+0fr8ylGr2R2faWMhq4lfEQc='), or a **nonce ('nonce-...')** is required to enable inline execution.`
 
You can safely ignore these warnings, since they are related to the reports that Page Shield requires to detect loaded scripts.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.shield.a: I received an alert about 'New dependencies from an unknown hostname'
You can perform a manual investigation by following the guidance provided in this article.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.apishiel: If you are experiencing problems with API endpoint discovery, latency metrics, or rate limiting calculations, click Start for an immediate solution.
Why are my API endpoints not found by API Discovery?

In most cases, this is due to the system not observing enough valid requests over a continuous period. API Discovery only looks at requests that satisfy all of the following criteria: - Requests must return `2XX` response codes from the edge. - Requests must not come directly from Cloudflare Workers. - At least 500 requests are made to the discovered endpoint within a 10 day period. Endpoints discovered using session identifiers will be labeled as such in the dashboard. If the endpoints are not discovered through session identifiers, they will be discovered using our machine learning-based API Discovery.
How does Cloudflare calculate the recommended rate limit for my endpoint?

Cloudflare uses both the volume and frequency of traffic to guide your recommended rate. We calculate the recommended rate value throughout the day, and the new calculation may equal the existing recommendation due to similar traffic profiles existing on your API. When we recalculate, we look at requests that happened in the last 24 hours. Refer to this article for more details. You can view the `P50`/`P95`/`P99` percentiles of your request count for more details under an endpointu2019s expanded view.
Why am I unable to access the data of an endpoint after deleting it?

Cloudflare will stop tracking performance data when you delete an endpoint and its previous data will not be stored. This means that if you add this endpoint again, the metrics will start tracking from the point that you save it.
Why am I not receiving threshold recommendations for my discovered API endpoints?

Thresholds can only be recommended for endpoints that receive sufficient levels of traffic that meet the following criteria:
 
 - Only requests with the same criteria as API Discovery are considered.
 - If traffic has been erratic or intermittent to this endpoint, the threshold might not show up. Cloudflare needs endpoints to receive sufficient valid traffic in any 24-hour period in the last 7 days or since the initial discovery of the endpoint to make statistically safe threshold suggestions.
 - Cloudflare also requires at least 50 distinct sessions to have accessed the endpoint in any 24-hour period in the last 7 days or since the initial discovery of the endpoint.
 
 
If you do not receive threshold recommendations for a discovered endpoint, you will see one of the following error codes:
 - `404 response`: Cloudflare has not seen sufficient valid traffic for this zone to generate recommendations.
 - `551 response`: Cloudflare has successfully generated recommendations at some point in the past, but we have not seen sufficient recent valid traffic to provide up-to-date recommendations.
Why am I not seeing latency metrics?

Latency metrics currently are not supported when a Cloudflare Worker is running on the URL, as the requests are not passed directly to your origin. Some Cloudflare products such asxA0Waiting Room are built on top of Workers, so the same limitations apply to applications using these products.
Why doesn't Schema Validation v2 support the fallthrough action?

The fallthrough action is currently unavailable in Schema Validation v2 (SV2). If you absolutely require the fallthrough action, then you should continue to use the Schema Validation v1 (SV1) dashboard.
How do I filter traffic with Schema Validation Version 2?

In V2, schema validation is now integrated with endpoint management. To learn more about Schema Validation 2.0, please refer to the `How to Configure Schema Validation 2.0` section in our Developers Documentation.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.firewall: Are you having issues with Firewall Rules?
Follow quick instructions and receive an immediate solution.
I am adding Allow and Bypass rules in Firewall rules, but it's not working, why?

**Using Allow and Bypass actions:** Firewall Rules support the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions, often used together. These actions are commonly used for handling known legitimate requests u2014 for example, requests coming from trusted IP addresses. **Important Note:** You cannot bypass the new WAF managed rules using the **Bypass** action, only the previous version of WAF managed rules. Review the supported actions table on how to use Allow and Bypass actions. **Using Skip action:** Custom Rules support the **Skip** action instead, which combines the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions. With the **Skip** action you can do the following: * Stop running all the remaining custom rules (equivalent to the **Allow** action) * Avoid running other security products (equivalent to the **Bypass** action) * A combination of the above.
I see an error 1020: Access denied when visiting a site
The common cause is: a client or browser is blocked by a Cloudflare customeru2019s Firewall Rules. To resolve this issue, follow the instructions in this article.
I don't want any traffic outside of Port 80 or 443

Because Cloudflare IPs can be used by multiple services and customers, TCP Ports 80 and 443 will accept connections - this is expected and necessary behaviour. You can ensure that no traffic reaches your services on these ports using the Layer 7 Firewall Rules. For more details, check Network ports article.
Why isnu2019t my regular expression pattern matching working?

If you are using a regular expression, it is recommended that you test it with a tool like Regular Expressions 101 or Rustexp. Also, note that the **http.request.method** field requires all-caps for method names (for example, POST).

This error can be returned in case of a compression issue at the origin web server, for example the origin web server is serving gzip encoded compressed content but is not updating the `content-length` header, or the origin is serving broken gzip compressed content. You can try to disable compression at your origin to confirm if this is the root cause of the errors. Please read our 5xx Client Error article for more details. If you need our Support team to investigate further, please provide the following in your case: - The time and timezone of a recent occurrence of the issue. - An example of full URL that resulted in the HTTP 502 response. - Output from browsing to `/cdn-cgi/trace` or a HAR file from an affected client.

Cloudflare runs a distributed network with presence in 300+ locations around the world. Many of these locations are inter-connected which allows our services to be always available for our customers. Under certain conditions it is possible a given Data Center observes a sudden increase of traffic. In these cases our automated processes will move traffic away from such location to a different Data Center making sure there is no impact for our customers. These traffic adjustments are mostly seamless and take only a few seconds. Still, it is possible that during this automated process some clients observe added latency and HTTP 502 errors. We do apologize for this inconvenience. You can find more information about our automated traffic management tools in this blog post.

Some incidents on the Cloudflare side may results in HTTP 504 Error being thrown. Please check for incidents where HTTP status code 5xx are specifically mentioned, or incidents related to network performance. Read our 5xx Client Error article for more details.

Please check if you are using the Cache API: look for the `Put`, `Match` or `Delete` methods inside the Workers code that matches the route or hostname of your resource. `cache.match` generates a 504 error response when the requested content is missing or expired. The Cache API does not expose this 504 directly to the Worker script, instead returning `undefined`. Nevertheless, the underlying 504 is still visible in Cloudflare Logs. If you use Cloudflare Logs, you may see these 504 responses with the `RequestSource` of `edgeWorkerCacheAPI`. Again, these are expected if the cached asset was missing or expired. Note that `edgeWorkerCacheAPI` requests are already filtered out in other views, such as Cache Analytics. To filter out these requests or to filter requests by end users of your website only, please refer to Filter end users. Read our Cache API errors article for more details.

You may see an influx of HTTP 504 responses with the `RequestSource` of `earlyHintsCache` in Cloudflare Logs when Early Hints is enabled, which is expected and benign. Requests from `earlyHintsCache` are internal subrequests for cached Early Hints, and they are neither end user requests, nor do they go to your origin. Their response status only indicates whether there are cached Early Hints for the request URI (200 on cache hit, 504 on cache miss). These requests are already filtered out in other views, such as Cache Analytics. To filter out these requests or to filter requests by end users of your website only, please refer to Filter end users. Read our Emit Early Hints article for more details.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.customru: Are you having issues with Custom Rules?
Follow quick instructions and receive an immediate solution.
I am adding a Skip action in Custom rules, but it's not working, why?

There are two possible causes: - The Skip action rule order is after the rule with the block/challenge action in the rules list - Currently, you cannot skip Bot Fight Mode, only Super Bot Fight Mode (refer to Skip phases for more details). Create a separate custom rule with a Skip action these instructions. The skip rule must appear before the rule with the block/challenge action in the rules list.
I see an error 1020: Access denied when visiting a site

The common cause is: a client or browser is blocked by a Cloudflare customeru2019s Custom Rules. You can fix this by either updating the Custom Rule or allowing the visitoru2019s IP address in IP Access Rules. Follow this article to learn more.
I don't want any traffic outside of Port 80 or 443

Because Cloudflare IPs can be used by multiple services and customers, TCP Ports 80 and 443 will accept connections - this is expected and necessary behaviour. You can ensure that no traffic reaches your services on these ports using the Layer 7 Custom Rules. For more details, check Network ports article.
Why is my regular expression pattern not working?

If you are using a regular expression, it is recommended that you test it with a tool like Regular Expressions 101 or Rustexp. Also, note that the **http.request.method** field requires all-caps for method names (for example, POST).
How do I exclude certain requests from being blocked or challenged?

In certain situations you want to enforce a blocking or challenging action but make an exception for specific types of requests. Cloudflare supports two methods of allowing requests using WAF custom rules: - Exclude a type of request from being blocked or challenged in a custom rule by updating the rule expression, for example adding an exclusion based on IP address, ASN, or country. - Create a separate custom rule with a Skip action. This skip rule must appear before the rule with the block/challenge action in the rules list. Check these examples that illustrate a few possible approaches.
I'm having issues with certain characters in expressions that may need escaping.
Some characters used in Firewall expressions will require escaping. The exact details depend on the string syntax you use. Check this article to learn more.
I unintentionally blocked traffic from known bots. How do I fix it?

When you create a WAF custom rule with a Block, Interactive Challenge, JS Challenge, or Managed Challenge (Recommended) action, you might unintentionally block traffic from known bots. Specifically, this might affect search engine optimization (SEO) and website monitoring when trying to enforce a mitigation action based on URI, path, host, ASN, or country. Refer to How do I exclude certain requests from being blocked or challenged?.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ratelimi: Rate Limiting
Need help fine-tuning rules, debugging rate limits and handling DDoS with rate limiting?
Follow quick instructions and receive an immediate solution.
Fine-tuning rate limiting rules and handling false positives or negatives with WAF Rate Limiting
Do you need help with fine-tuning your rate limiting rules?

Visit the Rate limit analysis tab in Security Analytics to determine the most appropriate rate limit for incoming traffic matching the applied filters. Also check the Find an appropriate rate limit page for guidance on fine-tuning your rules. This feature is available to customers on Business and Enterprise plans only.
Are you using a network or provider that uses Network Address Translation (NAT)?
NAT is commonly used in home or business networks where multiple devices share a single public IP address.
You cannot use both IP with NAT support and IP as characteristics of the same rate limiting rule. Explore general guidelines here.
Is legitimate traffic being blocked (false positive) by your rate limit rule?

Proceed with detailed troubleshooting steps below: - **Increase Rate Limit Threshold**: Adjust the threshold to allow more requests in the specified time frame. - **Add Exceptions**: Create exceptions for trusted IP addresses, user agents, etc. - **Review Logs**: Business and Enterprise plans can use Security Analytics to analyze logs and understand the origin and characteristics of blocked requests. - **Custom Rate Limiting Rules**: Create custom rate limiting rules to better fit the specific needs and traffic patterns of your site. - **Log Mode**: Use **Log** mode action to test new rate limit rules without affecting live traffic.
Is malicious traffic still getting through (also called a u201Cfalse negativeu201D)?

Proceed with detailed troubleshooting steps below: - **Adjust Thresholds**: If legitimate traffic is not being blocked despite exceeding expected thresholds, consider lowering the threshold to catch more requests. - **Check Log Analysis**: Business and Enterprise plans can analyze Security Analytics logs to detect traffic patterns that should trigger rate limits but currently do not. Adjust rules based on observed traffic patterns. - **Custom Rate Limiting Rules**: Create custom rate limiting rules tailored to specific endpoints or traffic patterns that are currently being missed.
Have you managed to resolve the issue with the guidelines provided?
No further action needed.
If you have followed this flow and still require assistance, please contact Customer Support or refer to the detailed documentation.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.turnstil: Turnstile and Challenge Platform
Need help with Turnstile latency, performance issues, infinite loops, or migration?
Follow quick instructions and receive an immediate solution for these common Turnstile issues.
Getting started with Turnstile
Are you having issues embedding Turnstile into your website?

u2022 Turnstile needs to be embedded into the page where the user wants Turnstile to load. This is called client side rendering. By placing the code snippet within the HTML code, you will be able to place the widget on a particular location. Refer to Client Side Rendering and Widget Types documentations. u2022 Once the widget is placed on the page, you will need to add in server side validation in the backend implementation. The widget, once loaded, will generate a token. This token is valid for 5 minutes and will need to be validated by the customer through siteverify API within that time frame. Refer to Server Side Validation documentation. u2022 It is important to retrieve the token generated from Turnstile and validate it by calling the siteverify API. Siteverify ensures that the token is valid. A token cannot be validated more than once, as we check for double redemption.
Do you need help migrating from reCAPTCHA or hCAPTCHA to Turnstile?

reCAPTCHA and hCAPTCHA are captcha services. We have migration guides to help easily switch over to Turnstile. The process should be simple and self-serve. Refer to migration guides here for reCAPTCHA and here for hCAPTCHA.
Are you having issues creating a new widget?
If none of the previous information has helped, please contact Customer Support.
Are you an Enterprise customer?
Please contact Customer Support to increase your entitlement.
Do you have 10 widgets?
You've reached your limit and need to upgrade to create more widgets. For upgrading, please visit the Turnstile Product page.
Does the **Hostname** field contains a properly formatted hostname?
When adding a Turnstile site, at least one hostname is necessary. The hostname does not need to be registered with Cloudflare.
Please contact Customer Support for further assistance.

You need to enter the hostname where you are placing the widget. For instance, if you want to embed Turnstile on `example.com/login`, you need to input `example.com` as the hostname when creating the widget. If the hostname is added and you still face issues, this might be a bug. Please check the Hostname Management article or contact Customer Support for further assistance.
Handling False Positives (humans getting blocked) & False Negatives (malicious traffic getting through)
Are you seeing significant traffic that you believe to be humans getting blocked?

u2022 If a human is mistakenly identified as a bot which resulted in a false positive, a feedback form will be presented to the visitor. This form will be submitted to the Turnstile engineering team for review. u2022 If you can replicate the issue, please generate a HAR file. If you are unable to obtain a HAR file, you will need to provide a Ray ID or QR code when debugging issues. The Ray ID is found at the end of the challenge page. You can obtain the QR code by clicking the success/failure/spinner logo on the widget four times. u2022 Generally, there should not be widespread instances of false positives where a significant number of legitimate visitors are blocked. If you notice a considerable amount of legitimate traffic being blocked, please provide the Turnstile widget sitekey for us to investigate further.
Is Turnstile not working for a particular web browser?
Check the list of supported browsers: Browser Support. If you are having issues with any of the browsers that should be supported, please provide a HAR file.
Is a CAPTCHA Solving Service (e.g., zenrows, playwright, etc.) bypassing Turnstile?
Are you a Free customer?
Visit our Community page for Turnstile support.
Please confirm if a solving service is bypassing Turnstile, either through a script or a paid service's API. If confirmed, share your method so we can address it. Please proceed to open a case.
Are you seeing other bot attacks bypassing Turnstile?
Please provide the IP addresses and timestamps when the issue occurred; this will assist us in blocking the specific bot. You can contact Cloudflare Support by completing the form below.
If you've gone through this process and still need help, please reach out to Cloudflare Support by filling out the form below.
Troubleshooting error codes
Are you getting `Error code 600010 The generic_challenge_failure`?

This error suggests that Turnstile has detected possible bot activity or irregular visitor behavior. If this appears during automated testing, it might be due to bot-like actions. Consider using a testing sitekey/secret key for your automated testing. Visit the Cloudflare Turnstile Testing Documentation for guidance.
Are you seeing a 401 error in your web console during a Turnstile security check?
You can safely ignore the error. It is requesting a Private Access Token (PAT) that your device or browser does not support yet.

If you encounter a client-side error with Cloudflare Turnstile, refer to the Cloudflare Turnstile Client-side Error Codes page. It provides descriptions, retry possibilities, and recommended actions for various error codes related to initialization issues, invalid parameters, API compatibility problems, and domain restrictions.
Problems with slowness and infinite loops
Are you experiencing latency issues completing the challenge?
This could mean the challenge takes longer than expected to load, the widget is too slow, or it keeps looping without completing.
The Turnstile widget needs to be refreshed to generate a new token. This can be done using the `turnstile.reset` function. Check the Turnstile Reset Function article for more details.
Are you experiencing an endless challenge loop?
If none of the above helped, please contact Customer Support for further assistance.
Do you have an up-to-date web browser?

If your visitors are using an up-to-date version of a major browser u2014 such as Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Microsoft Edge, Chrome, and Safari on mobile u2014 they will receive the challenge correctly. If the issue continues, move to the next question. See supported browsers link.
Challenges are not supported by Microsoft Internet Explorer. If your visitors encounter issues using a major browser besides Internet Explorer, they should upgrade their browser.
Have you disabled browser extensions, tested again, and found that the issue persists?
If you have browser extensions, they might lead to unpassable challenge loops. To fix this, disable your extensions and reload the page.
Are you testing using mobile device emulation?
Challenges are not supported when device emulation is enabled on a browser (for example, using the browseru2019s developer tools).
Is Javascript enabled?
Ensure JavaScript is enabled. Check the Enable JavaScript article for more details.
Did you try in incognito/private mode?
Test using incognito/private mode. Check this article for more details.
Are you behind a VPN or proxy?
This is a known product limitation. If your application is behind a VPN or a proxy, Turnstile may enter an infinite loop. Ensure you are not behind a VPN or proxy.
If none of the above helped, generate a HAR file for use in further debugging.

Youu2019ll need to check the SSL configuration on the origin web server directly. You might need help from your website administrator or hosting provider. The following resources might help: - Apache: SSL/TLS Strong Encryption How-To - NGINX: Configuring HTTPS servers

Alternatively, as a temporary workaround, you could try to use the Flexible SSL mode so that Cloudflare connects to your origin on the non-secure port 80, which doesn't require a certificate configured on your origin web server. Managed rules is blocking legitimate traffic (false positive)
In your Security Events, are you seeing requests being blocked by OWASP rule IDs 981176 or 949110?

1. Go to Security Events and follow these instructions on how to add a filter and analyse the Activity logs. 2. Expand the **Activity Log** section and you should see `Rule: 949110: Inbound Anomaly Score Exceeded` (for new Managed Rules) or `Rule: 981176: Inbound Anomaly Score Exceeded` (for old Managed Rules). 3. You could also configure payload logging and view the payload content in the dashboard. Please note that there isnu2019t currently a search function for Managed and OWASP rules by ID within the Security Events dashboard. Instead, you should look for the specific rule group and rule within the list of rules manually.
Have you modified the managed rule(s) responsible for the false positive?

- For old Managed Rules, check if the offending ruleu2019s default mode has been modified. - For new Managed Rules, review the override table and check if the offending rule's action/status has been modified.
Is the false positive persisting after implementing the changes?

If you see **Rule ID: OWASP Block (981176)** in **Security Events > Activity log**, then **Managed Rules (Previous version)** blocked it. To reduce false positives: - lower the Package: OWASP ModSecurity Core Rule Set card. - Bypass managed rules (previous version) with a firewall rule: Create a Firewall Rule with the bypass action to deactivate WAF managed rules for a specific combination of parameters. For example, bypass managed rules for a specific URL and a specific IP address or user agent. If you see **Rule ID: 949110: Inbound Anomaly Score Exceeded** in **Security Events > Activity log**, then **Managed Rules (new version)** blocked it. To reduce false positives: - lower the OWASP Anomaly Score Threshold or Paranoia Level. - Skip managed rules (new version) with custom rules: Create a Custom Rule with a skip action to deactivate managed rules for a specific combination of parameters. For example, skip managed rules for a specific URL and a specific IP address or user agent. - Add WAF Exception (for new managed rules): You can define WAF exceptions in the Cloudflare dashboard or using the Rulesets API. If the false positive is persisting after implementing the changes, consider reaching out to Cloudflare support for seeking further assistance.

I am adding Allow and Bypass rules in Firewall rules, but it's not working, why?

**Using Allow and Bypass actions:** Firewall Rules support the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions, often used together. These actions are commonly used for handling known legitimate requests u2014 for example, requests coming from trusted IP addresses. **Important Note:** You cannot bypass the new WAF managed rules using the **Bypass** action, only the previous version of WAF managed rules. Review the supported actions table on how to use Allow and Bypass actions. **Using Skip action:** Custom Rules support the **Skip** action instead, which combines the **Allow** and **Bypass** actions. With the **Skip** action you can do the following: * Stop running all the remaining custom rules (equivalent to the **Allow** action) * Avoid running other security products (equivalent to the **Bypass** action) * A combination of the above.
I want to check if certain vulnerabilities or CVEs are blocked by WAF/Managed rules

**If your domain is using the Managed Rules (new version):** - Go to Cloudflare OWASP Core Ruleset - Search for the CVE number (e.g. cve-2019-8943 or cve-2020) **If your domain is using the Managed Rules (Previous version):** * Go to Managed Rules * Under the **Cloudflare Managed Ruleset** card, click on the **Advanced** link * Search for the CVE number (e.g. cve-2019-8943 or cve-2020) **If the CVE is listed:** You can confirm whether or not the rulesets are active and which action they currently take, and make any changes to the **Action** or **Status** if necessary. **If the CVE is NOT listed:** * Older CVEs may not be in scope. We will only create rules for vulnerabilities with at least a **CVSS Attack Vector (AV)** of **NETWORK** with an exploit that **specifically uses HTTP/HTTPS** * Newer CVEs may not be disclosed/may lack sufficient information for Cloudflare to take action As information develops, these new CVEs will be reevaluated by our engineers. **What can I do if a CVE is not currently mitigated by the Cloudflare Managed Ruleset?** We currently only update our managed rule sets with recent CVEs or with CVEs that are affecting software components that are widely in use. If you believe this vulnerability meets this criteria, please continue to submit a case for further investigation. Otherwise, we advise you to build a custom Firewall rule. Check this documentation on how to build a custom Firewall rule. We aim to provide managed WAF rules that are generally applicable to our wide customer base to ensure that our WAF also has a very low false positive rate. Custom Firewall Rules are meant to be used to expand on that generally applicable coverage.
I have issues with migrating to the Managed Rules (new version)
Read the WAF Managed Rules migration article to check how to start the migration and review possible migration errors.
I'm seeing requests blocked or challenged by OWASP rules, such as rule ID 981176 or rule ID 949110 in the Security Events, how do I fix?

If you see **Rule ID: OWASP Block (981176)** in **Security Events > Activity log**, then **Managed Rules (Previous version)** blocked it. To reduce false positives: - lower the Package: OWASP ModSecurity Core Rule Set card. - Bypass managed rules (previous version) with a firewall rule: Create a Firewall Rule with the bypass action to deactivate WAF managed rules for a specific combination of parameters. For example, bypass managed rules for a specific URL and a specific IP address or user agent. If you see **Rule ID: 949110: Inbound Anomaly Score Exceeded** in **Security Events > Activity log**, then **Managed Rules (new version)** blocked it. To reduce false positives: - lower the OWASP Anomaly Score Threshold or Paranoia Level. - Skip managed rules (new version) with custom rules: Create a Custom Rule with a skip action to deactivate managed rules for a specific combination of parameters. For example, skip managed rules for a specific URL and a specific IP address or user agent. - Add WAF Exception (for new managed rules): You can define WAF exceptions in the Cloudflare dashboard or using the Rulesets API.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.billing_: Payment failure
Is your payment failing?
If you're having trouble paying for a Cloudflare invoice or upgrade, check here for immediate answers.
My payment is failing with Cloudflare

If youu2019re unable to add a payment method due to an error, or a specific payment is failing when you attempt to pay or renew, please try the following: **1. Check you are using a supported payment method** Review our Approved Payment Methods - Cloudflare only accepts VISA, MasterCard, American Express, Discover, Paypal, and UnionPay. No other payment methods (for example, Maestro) are possible at this time. **2. Retry the payment in an incognito or private browser** Some browser extensions or configurations can interfere with your payment processing. We recommend retrying the payment in your browseru2019s *private* or *incognito* mode. This will ensure no extensions can interfere with the process. **3. Check the common reasons for failed payment KB** If you have tried all of the above and your payment is still failing, you must talk to your bank to understand why they rejected the payment. Cloudflare has documented some common reasons for failed payments in our Troubleshooting Failed Payments guide which can help. If you have attempted all the steps above and your payment is still failing, you must contact your bank to understand the reasons behind the payment rejection. If the issue persists and the reason is unclear, please proceed to submit a case for further assistance from the billing team.
Cloudflare Invoices
Questions about Cloudflare Invoices?
If you're having trouble retrieving, updating or understanding your invoice, click Start for guidance.
I purchased a subscription, domain or new feature. When will I receive my invoice?
An invoice will be available on the Billing section of the Cloudflare dashboard within 24 hours.
Could you send me a new invoice with updated billing details?
Any billing updates or changes you have made will apply to all future invoices. Invoices already generated cannot be re-issued.
Where can I access my invoices?

You may download invoices from the Billing section of your Cloudflare account. **Note:** Only the Super Administrators for the account will be able to access invoices via Cloudflare's dashboard. Due to security reasons, we recommend that our customers access their invoices via account dashboard. To manually download your Cloudflare invoices:
  • Log in to your Cloudflare account.
  • Click the **Billing** tab.
  • On the left navigation, click **Invoices**. You will see all invoices associated with your account.
  • Click on the invoice number to Download.
Cloudflare Subscriptions
Looking for a subscription refund?
If you are looking for a refund after upgrading, cancelling or downgrading a subscription, click here to get started.
I have **upgraded** my subscription and am looking for a refund

As soon as you upgrade from any paid subscription our system will automatically calculate and apply a pro-rated credit for the time you didn't use on your previous subscription. To view your current credit balance, visit Payment Info and look for the **Credit Balance** section. **When can I use the credit?** This credit will be automatically applied to your future bills. Credits are valid for 3 years and can be used only for monthly or annual recurring subscriptions. Please note, it cannot be used for new orders or for yearly registrar domain renewals. For more guidance, refer to our Change domain plan guide.
I have **downgraded** my subscription and am looking for a refund

When you downgrade a subscription you will continue to receive the benefits and features of that subscription until the end date. Please note that no credit or refund can be issued in this circumstance. To understand when you will have the service until, visit the Billing > Subscriptions section and under the **Service Status** you should see **Ending On** and the relevant date next to it. You will continue to receive the service related to this subscription until this date. For more guidance, refer to our Cancel Cloudflare Subscriptions and Change domain plan guides.
I have **cancelled** my subscription and am looking for a refund

When you cancel a subscription you will continue to receive the benefits and features of that subscription until the end date. To understand when you will have the service until, visit the Billing > Subscriptions section and under the **Service Status** you should see **Ending On** and the relevant date next to it. You will continue to receive the service related to this subscription until this date. For more guidance, refer to our Cancel Cloudflare Subscriptions and Change domain plan guides.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.cache.op: Need a specific resource to be cached or want to improve how much is cached?
Answer some questions to get your Cache configuration working correctly.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.cache.ca: A resource is not being cached
Does the resource return a `CF-Cache-Status` response header?

Please check if you have an orange-clouded DNS record in your zone. Unless you have brought your own IPs to Cloudflare you should see an IP that belongs to a Cloudflare's IP range when running the following command in a terminal: `dig A "yourdomain.com" +short` You can validate that these IPs belong to Cloudflare by running the following command on a terminal: `whois 2>&1 | egrep 'NetName'` If the IP belongs to Cloudflare, the output should be: `NetName: CLOUDFLARENET` If you are using a Cloudflare Worker, please make sure to create a DNS record that is fully-proxied. You will need either a Custom Domain or a Worker Route for it, as you won't have cache control over resources that are served from a `*.workers.dev` subdomain. Content that is delivered through a domain (or subdomain) that isn't fully-proxied (orange-clouded) or not passing through Cloudflare's network, won't be cached. These assets won't be cached regardless of any Cache Rules or Workers set up for it.

You can check the cache status of your asset in Cloudflare by running the following command in a terminal: `curl -v 'resource url' 2>&1 | egrep '< cf-cache-status'` If the command returns some text containing one of Cloudflare's Cache Statuses (such as HIT, MISS, DYNAMIC and more) it means that the resource is most likely being proxied by Cloudflare. Learn more about the different cache statuses.
Is the resource returning a `CF-Cache-Status` response header with either the value DYNAMIC or BYPASS?

You can check the cache status of your asset in Cloudflare by running the following command in a terminal: `curl -v 'resource url' 2>&1 | egrep '< cf-cache-status'` If the command returns some text containing one of Cloudflare's Cache Statuses (such as HIT, MISS, DYNAMIC and more) it means that the resource is being proxied by Cloudflare. Learn more about the different cache statuses.

The response headers DYNAMIC or BYPASS show that the resource is not being cached. Several types of assets are cached by default, such as images, JS and CSS files. Other files, such as HTML files are not cached by default. You can force these resources to be cached using a Cache Rules. Please note that if your are handling cookies in a resource, such an HTML file, is usually not recommended to cache it as it may create issues with user's sessions. Also, please make sure that Development mode is not active, as it will disable Cloudflare's cache. Learn more on the Default Cache Behaviour section of our Developer Docs.

If you are seeing a HIT or MISS value in the `CF-Cache-Status` response header of your assets, it means that the asset is eligible for caching. Please review Default Cache Behaviour section of our Developer Docs as some file extensions are cached by default. If the file isn't included in the list of file extensions that are cached by default, please check for Cache Rules or Cloudflare Worker that might be causing this behaviour.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.cache.no: I want to improve how much my resources are cached

You can use Cache Analytics to see how many times a request was served from Cloudflare's cache. To understand how to review your cache performance using it, please read our Cache Analytics guide. With the intend to increase the cache ratio you can review whether your assets are cacheable and if not, to make them cacheable. The second aspect of improving cache ratio is to increase the time it takes for an asset to be purged. Please feel free to review our guide on how to accomplish this. The way assets are evicted from Cloudflare's cache is via an Least Recently Used (LRU) algorithm which means that assets that have a high TTL are still subject to eviction, specially if the resources are not being requested frequently. To overcome this and if your assets are eligible, please consider using Cache Reserve to increase the time for assets to be stored Cloudflare's Cache. If the overall goal to increase cache is to reduce the load on your origin servers (as well as potentially generating some savings), you may consider using R2 as an object storage, Cloudflare Images to store, transform, optimize and deliver images while Cloudflare Stream allows you to deliver your videos on demand. R2, Cloudflare Images and Cloudflare Stream allows you to serve content from Cloudflare.
