support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.le_c: I have an issue or question regarding the Letu2019s Encrypt chain update

For universal certificates, you do not have to take any action to prepare for this change, as they will automatically be switched to a more compatible certificate authority (CA). For advanced and Cloudflare for SaaS custom hostname certificates, refer to the How are your products affected guide to find out how the other types of Cloudflare Edge certificates might be affected. Important dates: - September 9, 2024: Cloudflare will stop using the cross-signed chain, both in certificate issuance and in certificate bundling. - September 30, 2024: The cross-signed chain will expire. As the IdenTrust cross-sign (DST Root CA X3) expires on September 30, 2024, the self-signed ISRG Root X1 will be the only chain used for RSA certificates issued through Letu2019s Encrypt. Refer to our blog post for details. Letu2019s Encrypt has been issuing RSA certificates through two chains: the self-signed ISRG Root X1 chain, and the ISRG Root X1 chain cross-signed by IdenTrustu2019s DST Root CA X3. As explained in the Letu2019s Encrypt announcement, the cross-signed chain has allowed their certificates to be widely trusted, while the self-signed chain gradually developed compatibility with various devices. As of late 2023, the number of Android devices trusting the self-signed ISRG Root X1 reached 93.9%, and Letu2019s Encrypt has decided to drop the cross-signed chain.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.rene: I have a question regarding certificate renewal

If you're using Cloudflare universal or advanced certificates on a Full Setup, Cloudflare will automatically renew these certificates without any action needed from your side. See our validity periods and renewal documentation for details about the auto renewal period depending on your certificate. If you're using advanced certificates on a Partial (CNAME) Setup, we recommend using DCV Delegation to facilitate the renewal process. You can find more details on when an action is required in our Domain Control Validation (DCV) article. For custom certificates, Cloudflare does not manage the renewal. You will need to make sure you upload a new certificate before the expiry date. You can find more details in the custom certificate renewal and expiration article. Please not that Cloudflare does not support key pinning because Cloudflare regularly changes the edge certificates (universal or advanced) provisioned for your domain and - if you had HPKP enabled - your domain would go offline. If you want to use Certificate Pinning anyway, the only advisable solution would be to use a custom certificate (available on Business and Enterprise plans). Also see our blog post on this topic: Avoiding downtime: modern alternatives to outdated certificate pinning practices.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.cust: I have an issue or question regarding a custom certificate
Have you already tried to upload your custom certificate?
You can upload your custom certificate under SSL/TLS > Edge Certificates.
Are you getting a 1xxx or 2xxx error when uploading the certificate?
Do you have concerns as the expiry date of your custom certificate is approaching?
Refer to our Troubleshooting custom certificates guide if youu2019re encountering any issues.

Cloudflare does not manage the renewal of custom certificates. You will need to renew the certificate with your provider, and upload the new certificate. There is no downtime related to this operation. If a valid replacement - covering some or all of the SANs in the expiring custom certificate - is already available, Cloudflare will remove the expiring custom certificate in the 24 hours before expiration. If no valid replacement is available, Cloudflare will remove the custom certificate after it expires and clients will encounter a certificate error. Read our Renewal and expiration article for more details.

Please make sure that your certificate is in the expected format, that the details are correct, and that it matches all the requirements. You can use the openssl tool to check the details of your certificate: `$ openssl x509 -in certificate.crt -noout -text` You can find more details about the specific 1xxx or 2xxx errors in our Troubleshooting documentation.

You will need to first acquire or generate the certificate from an external provider. The certificate will need to comply with the following requirements. You can upload your custom certificate under SSL/TLS > Edge Certificates, provided your zone is on a Business or Enterprise plan. Refer to our Troubleshooting custom certificates guide if youu2019re encountering any issues.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.digi: I have an issue or question regarding the DigiCert deprecation
Do you have an issue or question regarding Custom Certificates, Origin CA, or mTLS Client Certificates?
Do you need certificates with a validity period longer than 90 days?
Are you encountering device compatibility issues?
Older devices may experience compatibility issues with newer certificates, leading to certificate errors during connection attempts.
Are you pinning a Cloudflare Edge certificate? (Universal or Advanced)
You can find more details about HTTP Public Key Pinning here
Do you need to find all certificates that are using DigiCert in your account?

This migration only affects Universal, Advanced and Cloudflare for SaaS certificates that have been provisioned by Cloudflare using DigiCert as certificate authority. When existing Universal SSL or Advanced DigiCert certificates will be up for renewal, they will automatically renew with a new certificate authority: Letu2019s Encrypt or Google Trust Service. You donu2019t need to take any action in this case. For Advanced Certificate Manager and Cloudflare for SaaS, please consider each specific migration guide for actions you might have to take and refer to CAs and certificates FAQ for commonly asked questions about the Cloudflare offerings and CAs that are used. Other resources: - Read our DigiCert update article - Certificate and hostname priority - Browser compatibility - Cloudflare SSL/TLS concepts

You can use the Cloudflare API endpoint /ssl/certificate_packs to get these details. The `certificate_authority` is present in the response. ```curl -s 'https://api.cloudflare.com/client/v4/zones/$zones/ssl/certificate_packs' -H 'X-Auth-Email: $EMAIL' -H 'X-Auth-Key: $API_KEY' | jq -r '.result[] | .id,.type,.hosts,.certificate_authority'``` (You might need to install the jq tool - jq is a lightweight and flexible command-line JSON processor)

Cloudflare does not support HTTP public key pinning (HPKP) for Universal, Advanced, or custom hostname certificates, see our certificate pinning article If you need to pin a certificate on the Cloudflare Edge, you'll need to use a custom certificate. (A Business or Enterprise plan is required)

If youu2019re encountering issues with device compatibility, you have the option to select which certificate authority you wish to use at our edge yourself, by using Advanced Certificate Manager. If you wish to explore this option, it is available on the SSL/TLS > Edge Certificates page. You also have the option to upload your own custom certificate, but this does require a Business plan at a minimum. Read our Browser compatibility article for more details

Cloudflare only issues certificates with validity periods of three months or less for two reasons: - First, shorter-lived certificates limit the damage from key compromise and mistaken issuance. Any compromised key material will be valid for a shorter period of time. - Second, shorter certificates encourage automation. The more frequently you have to do a task, the more likely you will want to automate it. Automation also means that you are less likely to let a certificate expire in production or give a person access to key material. Read our Certificate Validity Period article for more details, and also see our blog on Advanced Certificate Manager.

The DigiCert deprecation only affects Universal, Advanced, and Cloudflare for SaaS certificates, where the certificate has been provisioned by Cloudflare using DigiCert as certificate authority. Cloudflare Origin CA certificates, Cloudlfare mTLS client certificates, and custom certificates are not in the scope and are not affected by this migration. Read our DigiCert update article for more details.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.ssl.othe: I am seeing a different problem or error
Are you seeing a browser / connection error?

Are you seeing a browser connection or SSL error mentioning any of the following terms? 
* NET::ERR_SSL 
* NET::ERR_CERT_ 
* SSL_ERROR_ 
* ERR_SSL 
* Invalid Certificate
Are you seeing a redirect loop?

If you are experiencing a redirect loop, you should see a browser error mentioning any of the following terms: 
* Too Many Redirects 
* This Page isn't redirecting properly 
* ERR_TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS
Are you seeing Mixed Content?
If you are experiencing mixed content, your website will appear broken with missing styling, images or functionality.

### Install Origin CA, set encryption mode to *Full Strict* and/or Enable *Automatic HTTPS Rewrites* Visit the SSL dashboard and check your SSL encryption mode - it should be to be set to *Full* or *Full (strict)*. If it is not, follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to install a valid certificate on your server. Then, set your SSL mode to *Full (strict)*. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin, you can downgrade your SSL mode to *Full* as an alternative. Typically, configuring *Full* or *Full (strict)* is enough to ensure your origin server also serves links correctly to avoid mixed content. If you still see mixed content and you do not know how to resolve this, you can try enabling Automatic HTTPS Rewrites. Lastly, you can review our troubleshooting mixed content article for more information.
Are you seeing the wrong website displayed?
When visiting your website, do you see a holding page or a completely different website to what you expect?

### Check your DNS is correct and configure your origin server for SSL To do this: 1. Visit the DNS settings for your domain and ensure that the DNS record for your website points to the hostname or IP address for your origin server. If you are unsure of the correct value, contact your origin server hosting provider. 2. Ensure your origin server is enabled to serve your site over HTTPS and Port 443. You can Visit SSL/TLS > Origin Server and follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to install a valid certificate on your origin if you need it. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin & configure your server for SSL, you can downgrade your SSL mode to *Flexible* however this may cause further issues and you may need to consult our guides troubleshooting mixed content and redirect loops to resolve these.

### Your website appears to be working Based on the answers you have given, your website is working over SSL and your problem is not covered by this wizard. You should go back to the start and check your answers carefully. If you are still having an issue, we recommend reading our SSL/TLS Get Started as well as our SSL Troubleshooting guides for further information.

### Install Origin CA, set SSL encryption mode to *Full Strict* Visit the SSL dashboard and check your SSL encryption mode setting - it should be to be set to *Full (Strict)*. If you encounter an error when loading your website with *Full (Strict)*, visit SSL/TLS > Origin Server and follow our deploy an origin CA certificate guide to install a valid certificate on your server - this will allow you to use *Full (strict)*. If you cannot install a valid certificate on your origin, you can downgrade your SSL encryption mode to *Full* as an alternative. As a last resort you can choose *Flexible* however if you continue to see redirect loops you will need to fix that issue at your origin server. Read our Too Many Redirects guide for further information.
Is your domain active on Cloudflare's nameservers?
Visit Your Websites and find your domain name. Does it say *Active* underneath the domain name?

### Set your nameservers correctly & check nameservers Visit Overview for your website and follow our setup guide to ensure you update your nameservers correctly. Once you have corrected these, click the *Check nameservers* button on the same page.
Is Universal SSL enabled for your website?
Visit edge certificates and check the Universal SSL setting. If you see a section titled *Disable Universal SSL*, then you know that it is currently *Enabled*.
Is your Universal SSL certificate active?

Visit edge certificates - do you see *Active*, *Pending Validation*, or another status next to the SSL certificate covering your hostname? Note: Typically, the certificate covering your hostname will be the wildcard cert, e.g., example.com, *.example.com?
Is the hostname proxied?
Visit your DNS settings - do you see *Proxied* next to the domain or subdomain you are seeing the problem with?
Is your hostname covered by an edge certificate?
Visit your DNS settings - do you see a DNS warning 'This hostname is not covered by a certificate' next to the domain or subdomain you are seeing the problem with?

When a certificate is active and the hostname is proxied, you should not run into any issue. Please make sure that you are not pinning the Cloudflare edge certificate or the root CA, as it might lead to an issue when the certificate automatically renews. If you want to use certificate or root CA pinning anyway, the only advisable solution would be to use a custom certificate (available on Business and Enterprise plans). Also see our blog post on this topic Avoiding downtime: modern alternatives to outdated certificate pinning practices. If you are still having an issue, we recommend reading our SSL/TLS Get Started as well as our SSL Troubleshooting guides for further information.

### Toggle Universal SSL To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click *Disable Universal SSL* * Wait 5 minutes and then click *Enable Universal SSL* and wait 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again

Universal SSL certificates only support SSL for the root or first-level subdomains such as `example.com` and `www.example.com`. To enable SSL support on second, third, and fourth-level subdomains such as `dev.www.example.com` or `app3.dev.www.example.com`, you can: - Purchase Advanced Certificate Manager to order advanced certificates. - Upgrade to a Business or Enterprise plan to upload custom certificates. Once youu2019ve purchased an advanced certificate, you can also enable Total TLS to get proxied hostname automatically covered: 1. Visit edge certificates and click the switch to enable Total TLS. 2. When the certificate status for the hostname you are seeing the issue with shows as *Active*, you can test your website again.

### Set the hostname to proxied. To do this: 1. Visit your DNS settings and find the DNS record for your website hostname. 2. Click *Edit* and set the Proxy status to *Proxied*. 3. Wait 5 minutes and then test again.
Is your Universal SSL certificate *Pending Validation*?

Visit edge certificates - do you see u201CPending Validationu201D or another status next to the SSL certificate covering your hostname? Note: Typically, this will be the wildcard cert, e.g., example.com, *.example.com.
Does your domain have invalid DNSSEC?

To check this: * Visit letsdebug.net and enter your domain name. * Choose *DNS-01* and click *Run Test*. Once the test has completed, do you see a warning as in this example mentioning *DNSLookupFailed* and *fatal DNSSEC issues*?

### Fix your invalid DNSSEC. Your domainu2019s DNSSEC is broken at your domain registrar - a registrar is the company that you pay for your domain registration. To fix this: 1. Follow our guide to Enable DNSSEC on Cloudflare to fix this. 2. Test your domain again using letsdebug.net to ensure the *fatal DNSSEC issues* message is removed. 3. Visit the edge certificates dashboard and click *Disable Universal SSL*; wait 5 minutes and click *Enable Universal SSL* again - the certificate should become *Active* within around 15 minutes.

### Toggle Universal SSL. To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click *Disable Universal SSL*. * Wait 5 minutes, then click *Enable Universal SSL*, and wait 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue. * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again.

### Toggle Universal SSL To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click *Disable Universal SSL*. * Wait 5 minutes and then click *Enable Universal SSL*; wait 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue. * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again.

### Enable Universal SSL for your website To do this: * Visit edge certificates and click the *Enable Universal SSL* button * Wait around 15 minutes for your Universal SSL certificate to issue * When the certificate status shows as *Active*, you can test your website again
support.portal.self-help-wizard.registra: Transferring a domain to Cloudflare Registrar
Having trouble starting or completing your transfer to Cloudflare Registrar?
If you cannot start your transfer or your transfer has not completed, check here for immediate answers.
Why do I see **"transfer conditions not met"** or no option to transfer my domain to Cloudflare?

Why do I see u201Ctransfer conditions not metu201D or no option to transfer my domain to Cloudflare? **1. Check your domain TLD is supported** Registrar only supports specific Top Level Domains (TLD). Visit TLD Policies - if your TLD is not listed as available, you cannot use Cloudflare as your domain Registrar at this time. Cloudflare Support is unable to confirm when a specific TLD will go live. **2. Check your domain name is supported** *Registrar does not support Premium domains*. To check if your domain is premium, enter your domain into Google Domains Search - if you see the Premium label, you cannot use Cloudflare as your domain Registrar at this time. *Registrar does not support Internalionalisted Domain Names (IDNs).* Does your domain name start with `xn--`? Currently, Internationalised Domain Names (IDNs) are not supported and you cannot use Cloudflare as your domain Registrar at this time. **3. Check the domain expiry** If your domain is due to expire within 15 days (or within 10 days for `.uk` TLDs), you must first renew the domain at your current domain registrar. Once you have done this, you can then transfer to Cloudflare Registrar. **4. Check the domain is Active with Cloudflare** The domain must be added to your Cloudflare account already and have a status of u201CActiveu201D. Visit the Dashboard - if you do not see `Active` underneath your domain name, click the domain name and follow the on screen instructions. Once the domain is Active, you can start the Registrar transfer process with Cloudflare. **5. Check the domain's WHOIS status** Visit a WHOIS service such as who.is and check the Status field. You will not be able to start a transfer to another Registrar if you see any of the following listed: * clientTransferProhibited * serverTransferProhibited * serverHold You must contact your current Registrar to ensure these statuses are removed before you can start a transfer to Cloudflare Registrar. **6. Check you have a valid credit card on file** Visit Payment info and ensure a working payment method is entered. You should also review our Registrar Get Started guide and FAQ. Note: Our Registrar support team can only assist if all of the above have been checked by you. If all of these checks look good and you still see `transfer conditions not met` and cannot start the transfer process, please close this and click `Add more details` to raise a case with the Cloudflare Support team.
I cannot change my nameservers to Cloudflare at my current registrar

You will be unable to transfer a domain to Cloudflare Registrar unless nameservers are set correctly to the ones designated in your Cloudflare account.

If your current registrar does not permit changes to 3rd party nameservers before starting a transfer, you cannot use Cloudflare Registrar at this time.
Why is my domain transfer stuck in **"Transfer In Progress"**?

This means that your request has been submitted by Cloudflare to your previous registrar. The process can take up to 5 days - please wait until then. 

To help speed things up - if after 24 hours you continue to see this status, try:

* **Contact your current registrar** and confirm the domain has been unlocked
* **Disable WHOIS privacy** at your current registrar

If the status is still present after 5 days, you should contact Cloudflare support for additional guidance. Please note Cloudflare Support will be unable to assist until you have attempted all of the above and waited 5 days.
Why is my domain transfer stuck in **"Pending approval"**?

This means that your transfer request is with your current Registrar - it can take them up to 5 days to release the domain.

To move faster, you can contact your current Registrar or log in to their dashboard to see if you can manually approve it. Cloudflare cannot speed up this process, so you must contact your current Registrar to assist further. 

If you are still seeing this status 5 days after confirming the domain is released you should contact Cloudflare support for additional guidance. Please note Cloudflare Support will be unable to assist until you have attempted all of the above and waited 5 days.
This means that you or your registrar may have canceled the transfer request. You can visit the Transfer Domains page and select **Retry** to initiate a new transfer request.
Why is my auth code not working?

If your authorisation code is not being accepted, try the following: * Open an incognito mode or private browser, log in to the Cloudflare dashboard and try again. * **Do not** copy & paste the code as it may be including hidden characters and spaces. Carefully re-type the auth code exactly including the correct case for each character. * If the issue persists, contact your registrar and ask for a new code - only your current registrar can confirm & provide the correct code.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.zt_acces: Having errors or issues with Access?
Answer some questions to get your Access configuration working correctly.
I'm having trouble with Access
What issue are you seeing?
Select the option for your issue that relates to the most common problems. DESCRIPTIOn
I am having an issue with my Access application
Is your issue related to attempts to authenticate to a particular Access app?

Failed authentication attempts can be investigated using your Access logs in the dashboard. You can use these logs to get a breakdown of the failing policies. You should also check the User Identity to make sure they have the correct permissions to authenticate into the application.
Is the user seeing a 403 error when trying to access the app?
403 Forbidden errors can be returned from the application server, but can also be caused by misconfigured policies.
Are you using mTLS?

Mutual TLS (mTLS) authentication ensures that traffic is both secure and trusted in both directions between a client and server. It allows requests that do not log in with an identity provider (like IoT devices) to demonstrate that they can reach a given resource.

Please ensure the appropriate hostname has been added to the mTLS certificate in the dashboard, by reviewing how to generate a client certificate. Should problems persist, we recommend querying these events with GraphQL.

These errors will be related to device posture or connection information (policies based on IP, country, etc.) Please review the information in the Logs > Posture to see what the expected vs. received values were for each check. We recommend querying these events with GraphQL.
Are you using One-Time PINs (OTP)?
Short-lived 6-digit codes are sent to approved email addresses as an alternative to integrating an identity provider.

Please note an OTP will only be sent if the email entered passes your policies, which you can check in the Access Policies for the application in the dashboard. Make sure the users are configured in the Access policy correctly, and make sure to allow emails from `noreply@notify.cloudflare.com`. If you believe they should be receiving an OTP but aren't, please submit a case with a HAR file that captures their OTP request.
Are you using a service token?
Service tokens can be used to authenticate machines not listed by the Identity Provider.
Please ensure the token has been added to a policy with the `Service Auth` action.  It will not work as expected with an `Allow` or `Bypass` action.
Are you seeing a CORS error in the browser?

Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that uses HTTP headers to grant a web application running on one origin permission to reach selected resources in a different origin.  For a CORS request to reach a site protected by Access, the request must include a valid `CF-Authorization` cookie.

You can see if you're experiencing CORS errors by opening the Developer Tools on your browser (`F12` on Windows, `Command` + `Option` + `i` on Mac) and look for a message in the console with `Cross-Origin Request Blocked`.
This may require additional configuration, depending on the type of request - please review Access and CORS.

If you are able to, please contact Support with your Application ID and description of the issue you're having with as much detail as possible. Please include what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem, so our Support team can better assist you. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.

If you are able to, please submit a support case containing as much information as possible. Please include the App ID, what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.
Are you attempting to configure a SaaS application?

SaaS applications consist of applications your team relies on that are not hosted by your organization. Examples include Salesforce and Workday. To secure SaaS applications, you must integrate Cloudflare Access with the SaaS application's SSO configuration. Self-hosted applications consist of internal applications that you host in your own environment. These can be the data center versions of tools like the Atlassian suite or applications created by your own team. To secure self-hosted applications, you must use Cloudflareu2019s DNS (full setup or partial CNAME setup) and connect the application to Cloudflare.

For SaaS Applications, please follow the Add A SaaS Application documentation for the most common SaaS Application configurations. Please check if the SaaS app you are configuring is covered by one of our documented tutorials. If it is not, please submit a case letting us know which SaaS app you're trying to implement, what the error looks like & how it's replicated, along with a screenshot that captures an error. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.

For Self-Hosted Applications, please follow the Add a Self-Hosted Application documentation for how to configure a self-hosted application. If this is not helpful, please submit a Support case explaining the issue in full, including how it is replicated and if the setup has ever been working previously. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.
I am having an issue related to my Identity Provider (IdP)

Cloudflare Zero Trust allows you to integrate your organization's identity providers (IdPs) with Cloudflare Access.  Your team can simultaneously use multiple providers, reducing friction when working with partners or contractors.

Okta, Azure AD, and Google are common Identity Providers.
Is your issue related to SCIM?

By connecting a System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) provider, you can provision access to the Cloudflare dashboard on a per-user basis, through your identity provider (IdP). SCIM is currently available for all plan types, but SCIM for Dashboard SSO is only available for Enterprise customers.
Is your issue related to provisioning users for access to the Cloudflare Dashboard?

Please make sure you have followed our Provision with SCIM documentation, which contains different setup steps than the normal SCIM configuration. If you continue to experience problems after checking this documentation, please contact Support with your Application ID and description of the issue you're having with as much detail as possible. Please include what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem, so our Support team can better assist you. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.

Please check your configuration is correct using our Synchronizing Users and Groups documentation. We would also recommend checking the configuration at the IdP, for example that users & groups have been appropriately assigned. Finally, your provisioning logs at the Identity Provider may provide more information on what's going wrong. Should issues persist, please contact Support with your Application ID and description of the issue you're having with as much detail as possible. Please include what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem, so our Support team can better assist you.
Do you see an error that says `Failed to fetch user/group information from the identity provider?`

To test if an IdP is correctly configured, go to Settings > Authentication. Next, select Test next to the IdP you would like to test. This will attempt to connect to the IdP to verify if a valid connection is established.

This is an indication that the communication between Cloudflare and your Identity Provider has broken, and your IdP isn't sending us the information that we expect. Please check your configuration, using the Identity Provider Integration documentation to test your IdP connection from both ends, paying particular attention to any secrets, etc. that could have expired.
Is the user receiving an unexpected decision?
For example, a blocked request might be due to a misconfigured policy.

Please review the decisions in Logs > Access. For blocks, you'll be able to see why they didn't pass for each policy. Additionally, you can test your policy directly in the Cloudflare One Dashboard. See the Policy Management Developer Documents for more details.

If you are able to, please contact Support with your Application ID and description of the issue you're having with as much detail as possible. Please include what's going wrong vs. what the expected behavior is, and how you're replicating the problem, so our Support team can better assist you. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.
I am having an issue with my users or seats
Do you require more seats or are you concerned about nearing your seat limit?

You can automatically expire seats in order to manage your seat count. If you need more than 50 seats, you can upgrade your plan by heading over to the Cloudflare Dashboard Plan Settings page. If you are on an Enterprise plan, please contact the Customer Success team by emailing Care@cloudflare.com.
Are you looking to delete a user or their seat?
Please note that users cannot be completely removed from appearing in the dashboard. You can, however, choose to revoke or remove users at any time - for help with this please see Seat Management.
Do you have a problem with a user's identity?
For example, they do not appear to belong to the expected groups from your IdP.

Please note that Access and WARP will evaluate identity based on a user's last-known state.  If a user authenticates via your IdP, but later authenticates with a different method, for example, via One-Time PINs (OTP), Access will no longer evaluate their IdP group memberships.

If you are able to, please submit a Support case explaining the issue in full, including how it is replicated and if the setup has ever been working previously. Otherwise, please head over to our Community to get help on your issue.
I have a question or issue related to SSO for the Cloudflare Dashboard
Are you looking to set up SSO for the first time?
You can configure your Identity Provider (IdP) to make Single Sign-on requests the Cloudflare Dashboard. Dashboard SSO is an Enterprise-only feature at this time.

If you are an Enterprise customer, please follow the steps to configure your Identity Provider outlined on Setting up Cloudflare dashboard SSO and reach out to your Account Manager for the next steps.
Are you trying to initiate the login without first visiting https://dash.cloudflare.com?

An IdP-initiated login looks something like this:
  1. A user logs into the identity provider.
  2. The user clicks on the application they want to access in the IP catalog.
  3. The identity provider packages the user's identity, pertinent information, and what the user can access into an XML-based SAML assertion.

Please note that IdP-initiated logins are not officially supported at this time.  We would suggest using https://dash.cloudflare.com to begin your login.  If you would like to open a feature request, please contact the Customer Success team.

You can temporarily un-enforce SSO via Settings > Authentication in the Zero Trust Dashboard. Please check your identity provider configuration here too, as the most common cause of these issues is an expired secret or other incorrect data in the IdP config.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.zt_gatew: Seeing issues with Gateway policies, HTTP block pages or HTTP errors?
Answer some questions to get your Gateway configuration working correctly.
I'm having trouble with Gateway
What issue are you seeing?
Select the option for your issue that relates to the most common problems. DESCRIPTIOn
I am seeing an unexpected Gateway block page
Is the block page related to a domain categorization?

Cloudflare categorizes domains into content categories and security categories, which cover security risks and security threats. Domain categorizations include malware, adult content, or phishing. You can verify a domain's categorization on Cloudflare Radar.
Are you the Super Admin of the domain?
If you believe this domain to be miscategorized, please submit a domain categorization in your Cloudflare Dashboard Security Center. More details can be found in our Developer Documentation.
If you believe this domain to be miscategorized, please submit a domain categorization on the Cloudflare Radar page.
Make sure to Test DNS Filtering in order to ensure the correct behavior. You can also reference some of the more common policies as a reference guide.
I am not seeing my policy match
I am having a DNS issue
Is the block page related to a domain categorization?

Domain categorizations include malware, adult content, or phishing. This can show up as a false negative due to a misconfigured policy. DNS pre-resolution & post resolution rules work from top-to-bottom. You can verify a domain's categorization on Cloudflare Radar.
If you believe this domain to be miscategorized, please submit a domain categorization on the Cloudflare Radar page, or in your Cloudflare Dashboard Security Center.
Make sure to Test DNS Filtering in order to ensure the correct behavior. You can also reference some of the more common policies as a reference guide.
I am having a Network policy issue
Are you using Dedicated Egress?

Network policies include blocking specific protocols or restricting access to private networks. Dedicated egress IPs are static IP addresses that can be used to allowlist traffic from your organization. * Only available on Enterprise plans.

With network and egress rules, the first match on a policy wins. Make sure to review the Order of Enforcement, placing more specific rules above catch-all or generalized rules. It is helpful to review the Gateway Logs for which policy matched first. You can find the Gateway Logs on the Cloudflare Dashboard.

The policy may not be triggering the correct conditions that you expect. Make sure to review the Order of Enforcement, placing more specific rules above catch-all or generalized rules. It is helpful to review the Gateway Logs for which policy matched first. You can find the Gateway Logs on the Cloudflare Dashboard.
I am having an HTTP policy issue
Is the application/website unresponsive or return HTTP errors?

Add a 'Do Not Inspect' rule to your Gateway policies for the application if it isn't working properly. Add a 'Do Not Inspect' policy if application or website uses certificate-pinning, and you are receiving a 'UNABLE_TO_GET_ISSUER_CERT_LOCALLY' error, as Gateway does not support TLS decryption for Mutual TLS. Add a 'Do Not Inspect' policy if the website has an invalid certificate and is returning a 526 error.

The policy may not be triggering the correct conditions that you expect. Make sure to review the Order of Enforcement, placing more specific rules above catch-all or generalized rules. It is helpful to review the Gateway Logs for which policy matched first. You can find the Gateway Logs on the Cloudflare Dashboard.
I am seeing a Gateway 503 Unreachable error
503 errors can be caused by a few different reasons
If you are able to temporarily disable WARP, is the site reachable without error?
Disabling WARP is a temporary troubleshooting technique that should validate whether the site is working as expected.  Disabling WARP may not be available, depending on configuration.
Are you the site administrator?
Do your origin logs indicate any evidence of Cloudflare being rate-limited or blocked?
See if your origin server is returning HTTP 429 error codes, or doesn't contain 'cloudflare' or 'cloudflare-nginx' in the HTML response body.

You can fix this by allow-listing the Cloudflare IP ranges, and taking note of any additional Cloudflare Egress IPs that may be trying to reach your origin. Please keep in mind that Cloudflare does not publish the Egress IP ranges in order to prevent abuse. Alternately, Enterprise customers have access to Dedicated Egress IPs which can be used to allowlist traffic from your organization.
Please open a case and include the Account ID, Policy ID, any relevant log entries from the dashboard, and timestamps for when the block occurred, which users were blocked, and on what domain/URL.
Please open a case and include the Account ID, Policy ID, any relevant log entries from the dashboard, and timestamps for when the block occurred, which users were blocked, and on what domain/URL.
Are you the site administrator?
This looks like an origin problem unrelated to Gateway or Cloudflare - check that your origin is reachable.
This looks like an origin problem unrelated to Gateway or Cloudflare - you will need to contact the site owner/administrator in question.
I am seeing a Gateway 526 Insecure error
If you are able to temporarily disable WARP, does the site operate without a certificate warning/error?
Disabling WARP is a temporary troubleshooting technique that should validate whether the site is working as expected.  Disabling WARP may not be available, depending on configuration.
Are you the site administrator?
These are the SSL configurations we support - you can either add a compatible certificate or deploy a Do Not Inspect Rule for this host

These are the SSL configurations we support. If you do not control the domain in question, your best option would be to contact them to see if they can deploy a compatible certificate, or as a last resort deploy a Do Not Inspect Rule for this host
The SSL certificate is expired or otherwise invalid. If you trust this site, you would need to add a Do Not Inspect Rule for this host
I am seeing 504 errors when browsing a website
Does the website take more than a minute to load?

504 errors can occur when a website publishes a `AAAA` (IPv6) DNS record, but does not respond over IPv6. While this is a known issue that Cloudflare is working to fix, you can solve this by either add the domain to your split tunnel configuration, or by adding a Gateway DNS policy to block `AAAA` records from that domain.

Make sure to understand the Order of Enforcement for Gateway policies, as the request may not be matching the policy correctly. It is helpful to review the Gateway Logs for which policy matched first. You can find the Gateway Logs on the Cloudflare Dashboard. You can also Test DNS Filtering by running simple commands from your terminal.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.zt_tunne: Having errors or issues with your Cloudflare Tunnel?
Debug and resolve your issue immediately
Debugging issues with Cloudflare Tunnel
My Tunnel isn't working
Is your Tunnel active?

You can check to see if your Tunnel is running by checking the status on the Cloudflare One Dashboard, or via terminal on the host machine using the command `$ cloudflared tunnel list`. Additional command lines can be found on the Tunnel Useful Commands on the Developer Documentation.

To run your Tunnel instance, make sure the host machine is on, Cloudflared is installed, and use the terminal command line `$ cloudflared tunnel run --url localhost:3000 `. You can find more examples of how to Run a Tunnel, or run Tunnel as a Service.
Is your firewall configured correctly?
In order to find out if your target machine's firewall is configured correctly, you can test connectivity with dig, or test connectivity with PowerShell.
In order for cloudflared to communicate with Cloudflare, the target machine's ports `443` and `7844` must be open. Please review the Destination and ports requirements and test again.
Can the machine running cloudflared connect to the IPs/service routed to this Tunnel?
You can confirm connectivity on the machine or host running cloudflared using Stream Tunnel Logs on demand. You can find more about Tunnel Logs on our Developer Documentation
Make sure cloudflared version 2023.5.1 or higher is installed on the host machine.
Are you running a Private Network Tunnel?

With Cloudflare Tunnel, you can connect private networks and the services running in those networks to Cloudflare's edge, as opposed to connecting to public hostnames. Private network routes can expose both HTTP and non-HTTP resources.
You are running a public hostname Tunnel - Raise a case with the Tunnel ID, and tunnel debug logs or stream logs on demand while recreating the issue.
Is the Network proxy enabled?
The Network Proxy for Gateway can be found in the Cloudflare One Dashboard, under Setting --> Network, and scroll down to the Firewall --> Proxy section.
Enable TCP/UDP/ICMP protocol proxy according to your use case.
Is the Tunnel configured with WARP routing enabled?

warp-routing is enabled by default for remotely managed Tunnels. Check the `config.yaml` file on the host machine to see if WARP routing is enabled. For private network Tunnels created through the dashboard, you can check the Cloudflare One Dashboard, under Settings --> Network, and scroll down to the Firewall --> Proxy section to see if WARP to WARP is enabled.
Enable or disable WARP routing according to your Tunnel management and configuration needs.
Have you configured Split Tunnels accordingly?

Split Tunnels allow you to route WARP-enabled devices outside of the Tunnel or to bypass Gateway entirely. You can find the Split Tunnels configuration on the Cloudflare One Dashboard under Settings --> WARP Client, then configure Device Settings.
Review when and how to use Split Tunnels for clarity on how to prevent interference with third-party applications, such as Office365 or VPN software.
Are you experiencing an issue with connection drops on long-live connection such as using SSH, RDP or VNC?

Long-lived connections initiated through the Cloudflare Zero Trust platform, such as SSH sessions, can last up to eight hours. However, disruptions along the service path may result in more frequent disconnects. Often, these disconnects are caused by regularly scheduled maintenance events such as data center, server, or service updates and restarts.
Raise a case with the Tunnel ID, and include the WARP diag .zip file, along with Tunnel debug logs or stream logs on demand while recreating the issue.
Is the issue happening 100% of the time?
Select No if the issue is happening intermittently.

support.portal.self-help-wizard.zt_warp: I'm having trouble configuring the WARP Client
When turning on the WARP Client, did all traffic to websites or apps stop working?

Some apps like Forcepoint and Mcafee Antivirus can take over a machine's DNS resolution, preventing the WARP Client from connecting to the Cloudflare edge. Try changing the machine's DNS resolver to 1.1.1.1/1.0.0.1, or configure your local firewall to allow the outbound connection.
When turning on the WARP Client, did specific websites or apps stop working?

You may need to configure a Split Tunnel or Local Domain Fallback so that the website or app's traffic is excluded from the WARP Client DNS resolution. If you need the traffic to come through Cloudflare's network, an alternate option is to configure a Gateway Rule for the website or application and set the action to 'Do Not Inspect'. Please take a look at our FAQ section, which might address the issue you're having.
Are you able to reproduce this on the most current version of the WARP Client?
Please upgrade to the latest WARP Client. We are constantly making improvements to the client and in many cases, a simple upgrade can fix the issues you're seeing.
support.portal.self-help-wizard.performa: Performance questions or issues

Are you concerned by the results of a speed test?
(GTmetrix, PageSpeed Insights, etc..)

To improve your performance, please run our Speed test under Speed > Observatory in your Cloudflare Dashboard: please then follow the guidance from the recommendations in the speed test result page. Once you have implemented the recommendations from our speed test, we recommend focusing on user experience instead of relying on speed test. Real user monitoring (RUM) is a web performance monitoring technique that collects and analyzes data based on actual user interactions and experiences, providing insights into how users interact with a website or application in real-time.
Are you trying to reduce your TTFB (Time To First Byte)?

Since Cloudflare acts as a reverse proxy, we might affect the TTFB for a proxied hostame (orange-clouded). There are a few HTTP requests that add up to the total TTFB: 1. Cloudflare successfully negotiating a connection with your origin. 2. Cloudflare sending a request on the connection. 3. The origin generating a response. 4. Cloudflare receiving the response. You may see a larger TTFB because we don't send data back until after we have connected to your web server and it has responded. The difference is usually no more than a few milliseconds. We recommend you read our blog post: Are you measuring what matters? A fresh look at Time To First Byte. The fastest TTFB you can achieve is by caching your content with us. As such, we recommend to make sure you are caching everything you can. You can use the Cache Analytics to determine if resources are missing from cache, expired, or ineligible for caching. As mentioned in the blog post, TTFB is not a good metric: Core Web Vitals are more meaningful metrics. You can run a Speed test under Speed > Observatory in your Cloudflare Dashboard: please then follow the guidance from the recommendations in the speed test result page.
I am not seeing my web site served by the nearest location on Cloudflare's network

Our network uses Anycast technology, which means that our IP addresses point to many servers. We currently have a presence in 300+ cities around the world, which all serve your site and DNS (see the network map). Visitors will typically reach the Cloudflare location closest to them. You can refer to our Identify the Cloudflare data center serving your request article for more details. Cloudflare locations can appear as `re-routed` or `operational` on our status page. You can also see the scheduled maintenance activities. Our network will automatically route traffic to different locations to maintain performance and reliability, for more information on this refer to our Traffic Manager blog post. Re-routing the traffic should have a minimal impact on the performance of your website. The most impactful thing you can do to improve the performance of your website is to run a Speed test under Speed > Observatory in your Cloudflare Dashboard: please then follow the guidance from the recommendations in the speed test result page.
I have a question or need assistance regarding a performance issue
Did you follow the recommendation of the Observatory test?
You can run a Speed test under Speed > Observatory in your Cloudflare Dashboard. You can then read our Understand test results article for more details.
Is the value of the `Server` header `Cloudflare`?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers; see our documentation.
Is the value of the `cf-cache-status` header `HIT` for this request?
You can use the Developer Tools in your browser or the `curl` command line tool with the `-v` option to get more details on the response headers; see our documentation.
Is the requested asset an image?

You can use Cloudflare Polish to automatically optimize images in your site. (please note Polish only applies to cached assets) You can also check Cloudflare Images. Images are typically a static, cacheable asset and are cached by default. You can use the Cache Analytics to determine if resources are missing from cache, expired, or ineligible for caching. Cache stores copies of frequently accessed content (such as images, videos, or webpages) in geographically distributed data centers that are located closer to end users than origin servers, reducing server load and improving website performance. You can use Cache Rules to fine-tune your caching settings. Tiered Cache can help you improve the cache hit ratios by using the size of Cloudflareu2019s network to reduce requests to your origin web servers. You may also consider using Argo Smart Routing to improve performance, especially if you get traffic from visitors located far away from your origin web servers. Finally, you should make sure there are no performance issues on your origin web servers that could affect the delivery of assets. The Linux htop or vmstat commands might help you investigate if you are running a Linux server. You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to check these details.

The Linux htop or vmstat commands might help you investigate if you are running a Linux server. You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to check these details.

If you are encountering slow performance for cached assets, please gather evidences and then reach out in the Community or raise a support case: - Provide a HAR file. - Provide an MTR or a traceroute. Please make sure you can identify a specific URL that is slow so you can get effective support. It needs to be the URL of a specific resource, like an image, a css file, a script, a specific html page, etc. You can use the Developer Tools in your browser to identify resources that are taking longer to load. The Network tab of the Developer Tools will show all the requests made by your browser when loading the web page with timing detail. You can also use the `curl` command line tool to get performance details for a single request: ```curl -svo /dev/null 'https://example.com/file' -w '\nTime Connect: %{time_connect} \nName Lookup Time: %{time_namelookup} \nTime Pretransfer: %{time_pretransfer} \nTime Redirect: %{time_redirect} \nTime Start Transfer: %{time_starttransfer} \nTime Total: %{time_total}' 2>&1 | grep -E '< HTTP|cf-ray|Time'``` Read the Troubleshoot requests with curl section of our documentation for more details. If you are not able to identify which specific requests are slow, you might need help from your website administrator, website developer or hosting provider.

That means that the resources were not proxied by Cloudflare, or that youu2019re looking at third-party requests (not loaded from your hostname or domain). None of the performance optimizations, like caching, were applied. Please make sure you set the proxy status of the hostname to Proxied (orange-cloud) in the DNS tab of your Cloudflare Dashboard. You should also make sure there are no performance issues on your origin web servers that could affect the delivery of assets. The Linux htop or vmstat commands might help you investigate if you are running a Linux server. You might need to contact your hosting provider or website administrator to check these details.
